respStmt.name: Kyonnah Price with homographing and regularisation completed by Alexis Antonia

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Baptista; Gentleman of Padua Katherina; the Shrew; daughter to Baptista Bianca; daughter to Baptista Petruchio; Gentleman of Verona; Katherine's suitor Vincentio; old gentleman of Pisa Lucentio; son to Vincentio; in love with Bianca Gremio; suitor to Bianca Hortensio; suitor to Bianca Multiple Speakers
Tranio; Lucentio's servant Biondello; Lucentio's servant Grumio; Petruchio's lackey Curtis; serving-man to Petruchio Christopher Sly; a drunken tinker Nathaniel; Petruchio's servant Philip; Petruchio's servant Joseph; Petruchio's servant Nicholas; Petruchio's servant Peter; Petruchio's servant
A Lord A Hostess A Pedant of Mantua A Widow First Huntsman Second Huntsman A Servant A Player First Servant Second Servant Third Servant A Messenger A Page Haberdasher Tailor

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following

div2.stage: Enter Begger and Hostes, Christophero Sly.

sp.speaker: Begger.
sp.p: I will feeze you i'faith.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A pair of stocks you rogue.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p:
You are a baggage, the Slies are no
Rogues. Look in the Chronicles, we came
in with Richard Conqueror: therefore Paucas pallabris, let the world slide: Sessa.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p:
No, not a denier: go by S. Ieronimie, go to thy
cold bed, and warm thee.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I know my remedy, I must go fetch the Headborough.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p:
Third, or fourth, or fifth Borough, I will answer
him by Law. I will not budge an inch boy: Let him come,
and kindly.

div2.stage: Winde hornes. Enter a Lord from hunting, with his traine.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Huntsman I charge thee, tender well my hounds,
Brach Meriman, the poor Cur is embossed,
And couple Clowder with the deep-mouthed brach,
Sawest thou not boy how Silver made it good
At the hedge corner, in the couldest fault,
I would not loose the dog for twenty pound.

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: Why Belman is as good as he my Lord,
He cried upon it at the merest loss,
And twice today picked out the dullest scent,
Trust me, I take him for the better dog.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Thou art a Fool, if Echo were as fleet,
I would esteem him worth a dozen such:
But sup them well, and look unto them all,
Tomorrow I intend to hunt again.

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: What is here? One dead, or drunk? See doth
he breath?

sp.speaker: 2.Hun.
sp.l: He breathes my Lord. Were he not warmed
with Ale, this were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: O monstrous beast, how like a swine he lies.
Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image:
Sirs, I will practise on this drunken man.
What think you, if he were conveyed to bed,
Wrapped in sweet clothes: Rings put upon his fingers:
A most delicious banquet by his bed,
And brave attendants near him when he wakes,
Would not the beggar then forget himself?

sp.speaker: 1.Hun.
sp.l: Believe me Lord, I think he cannot choose.

sp.speaker: 2.H.
sp.l: It would seem strange unto him when he waked

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Even as a flattering dream, or worthless fancy.
Then take him up, and manage well the jest:
Carry him gently to my fairest Chamber,
And hang it round with all my wanton pictures:
Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters,
And burn sweet Wood to make the Lodging sweet:
Procure me Music ready when he wakes,
To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound:
And if he chance to speak, be ready straight
(And with a low submissive reverence)
Say, what is it your Honour will command:
Let one attend him with a silver Basin
Full of Rose-water, and bestrewed with Flowers,
Another bear the Ewer: the third a Diaper,
And say wilt please your Lordship cool your hands.
Someone be ready with a costly suite,
And ask him what apparel he will wear:
Another tell him of his Hounds and Horse,
And that his Lady mourns at his disease,
Persuade him that he hath been Lunatic,
And when he says he is, say that he dreams,
For he is nothing but a mighty Lord:
This do, and do it kindly, gentle sirs,
It will be pastime passing excellent,
If it be husbanded with modesty.

sp.speaker: 1.Hunts.
sp.l: My Lord I warrant you we will play our part
As he shall think by our true diligence
He is no less than what we say he is.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Take him up gently, and to bed with him,
And each one to his office when he wakes.
Sirrah, go see what Trumpet it is that sounds,
Belike some Noble Gentleman that means
(Travelling some journey) to repose him here.
How now? who is it?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: If it please your Honour, Players
That offer service to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Bid them come near:
Now fellows, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Players.
sp.l: We thank your Honour.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

sp.speaker: 2.Player.
sp.l: So please your Lordship to accept our
duty.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: With all my heart. This fellow I remember,
Since once he played a Farmers eldest son,
It was where you wooed the Gentlewoman so well:
I have forgot your name: but sure that part
Was aptly fitted, and naturally performed.

sp.speaker: Sincklo.
sp.l: I think it was Soto that your honour means.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: It is very true, thou didst it excellent:
Well you are come to me in happy time,
The rather for I have some sport in hand,
Wherein your cunning can assist me much.
There is a Lord will hear you play tonight;
But I am doubtful of your modesties,
Lest (over-eyeing of his odd behaviour,
For yet his honour never heard a play)
You break into some merry passion,
And so offend him: for I tell you sirs,
If you should smile, he grows impatient.

sp.speaker: Plai.
sp.l: Fear not my Lord, we can contain ourselves,
Were he the veriest antic in the world.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Go sirrah, take them to the Buttery,
And give them friendly welcome every one,
Let them want nothing that my house affords.
Sirrah go you to Bartholmew my Page,
And see him dressed in all suites like a Lady:
That done, conduct him to the drunkards chamber,
And call him Madam, do him obeisance:
Tell him from me (as he will win my love)
He bear himself with honourable action,
Such as he hath observed in noble Ladies
Unto their Lords, by them accomplished,
Such duty to the drunkard let him do:
With soft low tongue, and lowly curtsy,
And say: What is it your Honour will command,
Wherein your Lady, and your humble wife,
May show her duty, and make known her love.
And then with kind embracements, tempting kisses,
And with declining head into his bosom
Bid him shed tears, as being overjoyed
To see her noble Lord restored to health,
Who for this seven years hath esteemed him
No better than a poor and loathsome beggar:
And if the boy have not a woman's gift
To rain a shower of commanded tears,
An Onion will do well for such a shift,
Which in a Napkin (being close conveyed)
Shall in despite enforce a watery eye:
See this despatched with all the haste thou canst,
Anon I will give thee more instructions.
I know the boy will well usurp the grace,
Voice, gate, and action of a Gentlewoman:
I long to hear him call the drunkard husband,
And how my men will stay themselves from laughter,
When they do homage to this simple peasant,
I will in to counsel them: happily my presence
May well abate the over-merry spleen,
Which otherwise would grow into extremes.

div2.stage: Enter aloft the drunkard with attendants, some with apparel, Bason and Ewer,& other appurtenances,& Lord.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p: For Gods sake a pot of small Ale.

sp.speaker: 1.Ser.
sp.l: Wilt please your Lord drink a cup of sack?

sp.speaker: 2.Ser.
sp.l: Wilt please your Honour taste of these Conserves?

sp.speaker: 3.Ser.
sp.l: What raiment will your honour wear today.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p:
I am Christophero Sly, call not me Honour nor
Lordship: I never drank sack in my life: and if you give
me any Conserves, give me conserves of Beef: never ask
me what raiment I will wear, for I have no more doublets than backs: no more stockings than legs: nor
no more shoes than feet, nay sometime more feet than
shoes, or such shoes as my toes look through the over-leather.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Heaven cease this idle humour in your Honour.
O that a mighty man of such descent,
Of such possessions, and so high esteem
Should be infused with so foul a spirit.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p:
What would you make me mad? Am not I Christopher Slie, old Sies son of Burton-heath, by birth a
Peddler, by education a Cardmaker, by transmutation a
Bearherd, and now by present profession a Tinker.
Ask Marrian Hacket the fat Alewife of Wincot, if she
know me not: if she say I am not xiiii.d. on the score for
sheer Ale, score me up for the lyingest knave in Christendom.
What I am not bestraught: here's---

sp.speaker: 3.Man.
sp.l: O this it is that makes your Lady mourn.

sp.speaker: 2. Mar.
sp.l: O this is it that makes your servants droop.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Hence comes it, that your kindred shuns your house
As beaten hence by your strange Lunacy.
O Noble Lord, bethink thee of thy birth,
Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment,
And banish hence these abject lowly dreams:
Look how thy servants do attend on thee,
Each in his office ready at thy beck.
Wilt thou have Music? Hark Apollo plays,
And twenty caged Nightingales do sing.
Or wilt thou sleep? We will have thee to a Couch,
Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed
On purpose trimmed up for Semiramis.
Say thou wilt walk: we will bestrew the ground.
Or wilt thou ride? Thy horses shall be trapped,
Their harness studded all with Gold and Pearl.
Dost thou love hawking? Thou hast hawks will soar
Above the morning Lark. Or wilt thou hunt,
Thy hounds shall make the Welkin answer them
And fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.

sp.speaker: 1.Man.
sp.l: Say thou wilt course, thy gray-hounds are as swift
As breathed Stags: Aye fleeter than the Roe.

sp.speaker: 2.M.
sp.l: Dost thou love pictures? we will fetch thee strait
Adonis painted by a running brooke,
And Citherea all in sedges hid,
Which seem to move and wanton with her breath,
Even as the waving sedges play with wind.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: We will show thee Io, as she was a Maid,
And how she was beguiled and surprised,
As lively painted, as the deed was done.

sp.speaker: 3.Man.
sp.l: Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood,
Scratching her legs, that one shall swear she bleeds,
And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep,
So workmanlike the blood and tears are drawn.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Thou art a Lord, and nothing but a Lord:
Thou hast a Lady far more Beautiful,
Than any woman in this waning age.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.l: And till the tears that she hath shed for thee,
Like envious floods overrun her lovely face,
She was the fairest creature in the world,
And yet she is inferior to none.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Am I a Lord, and have I such a Lady?
Or do I dream? Or have I dreamed till now?
I do not sleep: I see, I hear, I speak:
I smell sweet savours, and I feele soft things:
Upon my life I am a Lord indeed,
And not a Tinker, nor Christopher Slie.
Well, bring our Lady hither to our sight,
And once again a pot of the smallest Ale.

sp.speaker: 2.Man.
sp.l: Wilt please your mightiness to wash your
hands:
O how we joy to see your wit restored,
O that once more you knew but what you are:
These fifteen years you have been in a dream,
Or when you waked, so waked as if you slept.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: These fifteen years, by my fay, a goodly nap,
But did I never speak of all that time.

sp.speaker: 1.Man.
sp.l: O yes my Lord, but very idle words,
For though you lay here in this goodly chamber,
Yet would you say, ye were beaten out of door,
And rail upon the Hostess of the house,
And say you would present her at the Leet,
Because she brought stone jugs, and no sealed quarts:
Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p: Aye, the woman's maid of the house.

sp.speaker: 3.man.
sp.l: Why sir you know no house, nor no such maid
Nor no such men as you have reckoned up,
As Stephen Slie, and old Iohn Naps of Greece,
And Peter Turph, and Henry Pimpernell,
And twenty more such names and men as these,
Which never were, nor no man ever saw.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p: I thank thee, thou shalt not loose by it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: How fares my noble Lord?

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Marry I fare well, for here is cheer enough.
Where is my wife?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Here noble Lord, what is thy will with her?

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Are you my wife, and will not call me husband?
My men should call me Lord, I am your good-man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My husband and my Lord, my Lord and husband
I am your wife in all obedience.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: I know it well, what must I call her?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Alce Madam, or Ione Madam?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Madam, and nothing else, so Lords call Ladies

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Madam wife, they say that I have dreamed,
And slept above some fifteen year or more.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Aye, and the time seems thirty unto me,
Being all this time abandoned from your bed.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: It is much, servants leave me and her alone:
Madam undress you, and come now to bed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thrice noble Lord, let me entreat of you
To pardon me yet for a night or two:
Or if not so, until the Sun be set.
For your Physicians have expressly charged,
In peril to incur your former malady,
That I should yet absent me from your bed:
I hope this reason stands for my excuse.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p:
Aye, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long:
But I would be loath to fall into my dreams again: I
will therefore tarry in despite of the flesh and the blood

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: Your Honours Players hearing your amendment,
Are come to play a pleasant Comedy,
For so your doctors hold it very meet,
Seeing too much sadness hath congealed your blood,
And melancholy is the Nurse of frenzy,
Therefore they thought it good you hear a play,
And frame your mind to mirth and merriment,
Which bars a thousand harms, and lengthens life.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Marry I will let them play, it is not a Comedy, a Christmas gambolled, or a tumbling trick?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No my good Lord, it is more pleasing stuff.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: What, household stuff.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: It is a kind of history.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Well, we will see it:
Come Madam wife sit by my side,
And let the world slip, we shall never be younger.

div2.stage: Flourish. Enter Lucentio, and his man Triano.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tranio, since for the great desire I had
To see fair Padua, nursery of Arts,
I am arrived for fruitful Lumbardie,
The pleasant garden of great Italy,
And by my fathers love and leave am armed
With his good will, and thy good company.
My trusty servant well approved in all,
Here let us breath, and happily institute
A course of Learning, and ingenious studies.
Pisa renowned for grave Citizens
Gave me my being, and my father first
A Merchant of great Traffic through the world:
Vincentio's come of the Bentiuolij,
Vincentio's son, brought up in Florence,
It shall become to serve all hopes conceived
To deck his fortune with his virtuous deeds:
And therefore Tranio, for the time I study,
Virtue and that part of Philosophy
Will I apply, that treats of happiness,
By virtue specially to be achieved.
Tell me thy mind, for I have Pisa left,
And am to Padua come, as he that leaves
A shallow plash, to plunge him in the deep,
And with satiety seeks to quench his thirst.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Me Pardonato, gentle master mine:
I am in all affected as yourself,
Glad that you thus continue your resolve,
To suck the sweets of sweet Philosophy.
Only (good master) while we do admire
This virtue, and this moral discipline,
Let us be no Stoics, nor no stocks I pray,
Or so devote to Aristotles checks
As Ouid; be an out-cast quite abjured:
Balk Logic with acquaintance that you have,
And practise Rhetoric in your common talk,
Music and Poesy use, to quicken you,
The Mathematics, and the Metaphysics
Fall to them as you find your stomach serves you:
No profit grows, where is no pleasure taken:
In brief sir, study what you most affect.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Gramercies Tranio, well dost thou advise,
If Biondello thou wert come ashore,
We could at once put us in readiness,
And take a Lodging fit to entertain
Such friends (as time) in Padua shall beget.
But stay a while, what company is this?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Master some show to welcome us to Town.

div2.stage: Enter Baptista with his two daughters, Katerina & Bianca, Gremio a Pantelowne, Hortentio sister to Bianca. Lucen. Tranio, stand by.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Gentlemen, importune me no farther,
For how I firmly am resolved you know:
That is, not to bestow my youngest daughter,
Before I have a husband for the elder:
If either of you both love Katherina,
Because I know you well, and love you well,
Leave shall you have to court her at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: To cart her rather. She is too rough for me,
There, there Hortensio, will you any Wife?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I pray you sir, is it your will
To make a stale of me amongst these mates?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mates maid, how mean you that?
No mates for you,
Unless you were of gentler milder mold.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I'faith sir, you shall never need to fear,
Iwis it is not half way to her heart:
But if it were, doubt not, her care should be,
To comb your noddle with a three-legged stool,
And paint your face, and use you like a fool.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: From all such devils, good Lord deliver us.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: And me too, good Lord.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Hush master, here is some good pastime toward;
That wench is stark mad, or wonderful froward.

sp.speaker: Lucen.
sp.l: But in the others silence do I see,
Maids mild behaviour and sobriety.
Peace Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Well said Mr, mum, and gaze your fill.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Gentlemen, that I may soon make good
What I have said, Bianca get you in,
And let it not displease thee good Bianca,
For I will love thee never the less my girl.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: A pretty peat, it is best put finger in the eye,
and she knew why.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Sister content you, in my discontent.
Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe:
My books and instruments shall be my company,
On them to look, and practise by myself.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hark Tranio, thou mayst hear Minerua speak.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Seignior Baptista, will you be so strange,
Sorry am I that our good will effects
Bianca's grief.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Why will you mew her up
(Seignior Baptista) for this fiend of hell,
And make her bear the penance of her tongue.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Gentlemen content ye: I am resolved:
Go in Bianca.
And for I know she taketh most delight
In Music, Instruments, and Poetry,
Schoolmasters will I keep within my house,
Fit to instruct her youth. If you Hortensio,
Or seignior Gremio you know any such,
Prefer them hither: for to cunning men,
I will be very kind and liberal,
To mine own children, in good bringing up,
And so farewell: Katherina you may stay,
For I have more to commune with Bianca.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p:
Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not?
What shall I be appointed hours, as though
(Belike) I knew not what to take,
And what to leave? Ha.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p:
You may go to the devils dam: your gifts are
so good here is none will hold you: Their love is not
so great Hortensio, but we may blow our nails together,
and fast it fairly out. Our cakes dough on both sides.
Farewell: yet for the love I bear my sweet Bianca, if
I can by any means light on a fit man to teach her that
wherein she delights, I will wish him to her father.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
So will I seignior Gremio: but a word I pray:
Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brooked
parley, know now upon advice, it toucheth us both: that
we may yet again have access to our fair Mistress, and
be happy rivals in Bianca's love, to labour and effect
one thing specially.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: What is that I pray?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Marry sir to get a husband for her Sister.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: A husband: a devil.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I say a husband.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p:
I say, a devil: Thinkest thou Hortensio, though
her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be
married to hell ?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Tush Gremio: though it pass your patience and
mine to endure her loud alarums, why man there be
good fellows in the world, and a man could light on
them, would take her with all faults, and money enough.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p:
I cannot tell: but I had as lief take her dowry
with this condition; To be whipped at the hie cross every
morning.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Faith (as you say) there is small choice in rotten
apples: but come, since this bar in law makes us friends,
it shall be so far forth friendly maintained, till by helping Baptistas eldest daughter to a husband, we set his
youngest free for a husband, and then have to it afresh:
Sweet Bianca, happy man be his dole: he that runs
fastest, gets the Ring: How say you seignior Gremio?

sp.speaker: Grem
sp.p:
I am agreed, and would I had given him the
best horse in Padua to begin his wooing that would thoroughly woe her, wed her, and bed her, and rid the
house of her. Come on.

div2.stage: Exeunt ambo. Manet Tranio and Lucentio

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I pray sir tell me, is it possible
That love should of a sudden take such hold.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O Tranio, till I found it to be true,
I never thought it possible or likely.
But see, while idly I stood looking on,
I found the effect of Love in idleness,
And now in plainness do confess to thee
That art to me as secret and as dear
As Anna to the Queen of Carthage was:
Tranio I burn, I pine, I perish Tranio,
If I achieve not this young modest girl:
Counsel me Tranio, for I know thou canst:
Assist me Tranio, for I know thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Master, it is no time to chide you now,
Affection is not rated from the heart:
If love have touched you, nought remains but so,

l.foreign: Redime te captam quam queas minimo.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: Gramercies Lad: Go forward, this contents,
The rest will comfort, for thy counsels sound.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Master, you looked so longly on the maid,
Perhaps you marked not what is the pith of all.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face,
Such as the daughter of Agenor had,
That made great Ioue to humble him to her hand,
When with his knees he kissed the Cretan strand.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Saw you no more? Marked you not how her sister
Began to scold, and raise up such a storm,
That mortal ears might hardly endure the din.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move,
And with her breath she did perfume the air,
Sacred and sweet was all I saw in her.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Nay, then it is time to stir him from his trance:
I pray awake sir: if you love the Maid,
Bend thoughts and wits to achieve her. Thus it stands:
Her elder sister is so cursed and shrewd,
That till the Father rid his hands of her,
Master, your Love must live a maid at home,
And therefore has he closely mewed her up,
Because she will not be annoyed with suitors.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ah Tranio, what a cruel Fathers he:
But art thou not advised, he took some care
To get her cunning Schoolmasters to instruct her.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Aye marry am I sir, and now it is plotted.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have it Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Master, for my hand,
Both our inventions meet and jump in one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tell me thine first.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You will be schoolmaster,
And undertake the teaching of the maid:
That is your device.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is: May it be done?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Not possible: for who shall bear your part,
And be in Padua here Vincentio's son,
Keep house, and ply his book, welcome his friends,
Visit his Countrymen, and banquet them?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Basta, content thee: for I have it full.
We have not yet been seen in any house,
Nor can we be distinguished by our faces,
For man or master: then it follows thus;
Thou shalt be master, Tranio in my stead:
Keep house, and port, and servants, as I should,
I will some other be, some Florentine,
Some Neapolitan, or meaner man of Pisa.
It is hatched, and shall be so: Tranio at once
Uncase thee: take my Conlord hat and cloak,
When Biondello comes, he waits on thee,
But I will charm him first to keep his tongue.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: So had you need:
In brief Sir, sith it your pleasure is,
And I am tied to be obedient,
For so your father charged me at our parting:
Be serviceable to my son (quoth he)
Although I think it was in another sense,
I am content to be Lucentio,
Because so well I love Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tranio be so, because Lucentio loves,
And let me be a slave, to achieve that maid,
Whose sudden sight hath thralled my wounded eye.
Here comes the rogue. Sirrah, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p:
Where have I been? Nay how now, where
are you? Master, has my fellow Tranio stolen your
clothes, or you stolen his, or both? Pray what is the
news?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sirrah come hither, it is no time to jest,
And therefore frame your manners to the time
Your fellow Tranio here to save my life,
Puts my apparel, and my countenance on,
And I for my escape have put on his:
For in a quarrel since I came ashore,
I killed a man, and fear I was descried:
Wait you on him, I charge you, as becomes:
While I make way from hence to save my life:
You understand me?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Aye sir, never a whit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And not a jot of Tranio in your mouth,
Tranio is changed into Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: The better for him, would I were so too.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: So could I i'faith boy, to have the next wish after, that Lucentio indeed had Baptistas youngest daughter. But sirrah, not for my sake, but your masters, I advise you use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies: When I am alone, why then I am Tranio: but in all places else, your master Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tranio let us go:
One thing more rests, that thyself execute,
To make one among these wooers: if thou ask me why,
Sufficeth my reasons are both good and weighty.

sp.speaker: 1. Man.
sp.l: My Lord you nod, you do not mind the
play.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p:
Yes by Saint Anne do I, a good matter surely:
Comes there any more of it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Lord, it is but begun.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.p:
It is a very excellent piece of work, Madam
Lady: would it were done.

div2.stage: Enter Petruchio, and his man Grumio.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Verona, for a while I take my leave,
To see my friends in Padua; but of all
My best beloved and approved friend
Hortensio: and I trow this is his house:
Here sirrah Grumio, knock I say.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Knock sir? whom should I knock? Is there
any man has refused your worship?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Villain I say, knock me here soundly.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Knock you here sir? Why sir, what am I sir,
that I should knock you here sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Villain I say, knock me at this gate,
And rap me well, or I will knock your knaves pate.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: My Mr is grown quarrelsome:
I should knock you first,
And then I know after who comes by the worst.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Will it not be?
I'faith sirrah, if you will not knock, I will ring it,
I will try how you can Sol,Fa, and sing it.

div2.stage: He rings him by the eares

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Help mistress help, my master is mad.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Now knock when I bid you: sirrah villain.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
How now, what is the matter? My old friend
Grumio, and my good friend Petruchio? How do you all
at Verona?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Seignior Hortensio, come you to part the fray?
Contutti le core bene trobatto, may I say.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Alla nostra casa bene venuto multo honorata signior mio Petruchio.
Rise Grumio rise, we will compound this quarrel.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Nay it is no matter sir, what he legs in Latin.
If this be not a lawful cause for me to leave his service,
look you sir: He bid me knock him,and rap him soundly sir. Well, was it fit for a servant to use his master so,
being perhaps (for aught I see) two and thirty, a peep
out?
sp.l: Whom would to God I had well knocked at first,
then had not Grumio come by the worst.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A senseless villain: good Hortensio,
I bad the rascal knock upon your gate,
And could not get him for my heart to do it.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Knock at the gate? O heavens: spake you not
these words plain? Sirrah, Knock me here: rap me
here: knock me well, and knock me soundly? And
come you now with knocking at the gate?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Sirrah be gone, or talk not I advise you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Petruchio patience, I am Grumio's pledge:
Why this a heavy chance betwixt him and you,
Your ancient trusty pleasant servant Grumio:
And tell me now (sweet friend) what happy gale
Blows you to Padua here, from old Verona?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Such wind as scatters young men through the world,
To seek their fortunes farther than at home,
Where small experience grows but in a few.
Seignior Hortensio, thus it stands with me,
Antonio my father is deceased,
And I have thrust myself into this maze,
Happily to wive and thrive, as best I may:
Crowns in my purse I have, and goods at home,
And so am come abroad to see the world.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to thee,
And wish thee to a shrewd ill-favoured wife?
Thou wouldst thank me but a little for my counsel:
And yet I will promise thee she shall be rich,
And very rich: but thou art too much my friend,
And I will not wish thee to her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Seignior Hortensio, betwixt such friends as we,
Few words suffice: and therefore, if thou know
One rich enough to be Petruchio's wife:
(As wealth is burthen of my wooing dance)
Be she as foul as was Florentius Love,
As old as Sibyl, and as cursed and shrewd
As Socrates Zentippe, or a worse:
She moves me not, or not removes at least
Affections edge in me. Were she is as rough
As are the swelling Adriatic seas.
I come to wive it wealthily in Padua:
If wealthily, then happily in Padua.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Nay look you sir, he tells you flatly what his
mind is: why give him Gold enough, and marry him
to a Puppet or an Aglet baby, or an old trot with never a
tooth in her head, though she have as many diseases as
two and fifty horses. Why nothing comes amiss, so
money comes withal.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Petruchio, since we are stepped thus far in,
I will continue that I broached in jest,
I can Petruchio help thee to a wife
With wealth enough, and young and beauteous,
Brought up as best becomes a Gentlewoman.
Her only fault, and that is faults enough,
Is, that she is intolerable cursed,
And shrewd, and froward, so beyond all measure,
That were my state far worser than it is,
I would not wed her for a mine of Gold.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Hortensio peace: thou knowest not golds effect,
Tell me her fathers name, and it is enough:
For I will board her, though she chide as loud
As thunder, when the clouds in Autumn crack.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Her father is Baptista Minola,
An affable and courteous Gentleman,
Her name is Katherina Minola,
Renowned in Padua for her scolding tongue.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I know her father, though I know not her,
And he knew my deceased father well:
I will not sleep Hortensio till I see her,
And therefore let me be thus bold with you,
To give you over at this first encounter,
Unless you will accompany me thither.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
I pray you Sir let him go while the humour lasts.
A my word, if she knew him as well as I do, she would
think scolding would do little good upon him. She
may perhaps call him half a score Knaves, or so: Why
that is nothing; and he begin once, he will rail in his rope
tricks. I will tell you what sir, if she stand him but a little, he will throw a figure in her face, and so disfigure her
with it, that she shall have no more eyes to see withal
than a Cat: you know him not sir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tarry Petruchio, I must go with thee,
For in Baptistas keep my treasure is:
He hath the Jewel of my life in hold,
His youngest daughter, beautiful Bianca,
And her with-holds from me. Other more
Suitors to her, and rivals in my Love:
Supposing it a thing impossible,
For those defects I have before rehearsed,
That ever Katherina will be wooed:
Therefore this order hath Baptista taken,
That none shall have access unto Bianca,
Till Katherine the Cursed, have got a husband.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Katherine the cursed,
A title for a maid, of all titles the worst.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace,
And offer me disguised in sober robes,
To old Baptista as a schoolmaster
Well seen in Music, to instruct Bianca,
That so I may by this device at least
Have leave and leisure to make love to her,
And unsuspected court her by herself.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Here is no knavery. See, to beguile the old folks, how the young folks lay their heads together.
Master, master, look about you: Who goes there? ha.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Peace Grumio, it is the rival of my Love.
Petruchio stand by a while.

sp.speaker: Grumio.
sp.l: A proper stripling, and an amorous.

sp.speaker: Gremio.
sp.l: O very well, I have perused the note:
Hark you sir, I will have them very fairly bound,
All books of Love, see that at any hand,
And see you read no other Lectures to her:
You understand me. Over and beside
Seignior Baptistas liberality,
I will mend it with a Largess. Take your paper too,
And let me have them very well perfumed;
For she is sweeter than perfume itself
To whom they go to: what will you read to her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What ere I read to her, I will plead for you,
As for my patron, stand you so assured,
As firmly as yourself were still in place,
Yea and perhaps with more successful words
Than you; unless you were a scholar sir.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: O this learning, what a thing it is.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: O this Woodcock, what an Ass it is.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Peace sirrah.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Grumio mum: God save you seignior Gremio.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: And you are well met, Seignior Hortensio.
Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola,
I promised to enquire carefully
About a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca,
And by good fortune I have lighted well
On this young man: For learning and behaviour
Fit for her turn, well read in Poetry
And other books, good ones, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It is well: and I have met a Gentleman
Hath promised me to help one to another,
A fine Musician to instruct our Mistress,
So shall I no whit be behind in duty
To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Beloved of me, and that my deeds shall prove.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: And that his bags shall prove.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Gremio, it is now no time to vent our love,
Listen to me, and if you speak me fair,
I will tell you news indifferent good for either.
Here is a Gentleman whom by chance I met
Upon agreement from us to his liking,
Will undertake to woo cursed Katherine,
Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: So said, so done, is well:
Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I know she is an irksome brawling scold:
If that be all Masters, I hear no harm.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: No, sayst me so, friend? What Countryman?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Born in Verona, old Butonios son:
My father dead, my fortune lives for me,
And I do hope, good days and long, to see.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: O sir, such a life with such a wife, were strange:
sp.l: But if you have a stomach, to it in Gods name,
You shall have me assisting you in all.
But will you woo this Wildcat?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Will I live?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: will he woo her? Aye: or I will hang her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why came I hither, but to that intent?
Think you, a little din can daunt mine ears?
Have I not in my time heard Lions roar?
Have I not heard the sea, puffed up with winds,
Rage like an angry Boar, chafed with sweat?
Have I not heard great Ordnance in the field?
And heavens Artillery thunder in the skies?
Have I not in a pitched battle heard
Loud larums, neighing steeds, and trumpets clang?
And do you tell me of a woman's tongue?
That gives not half so great a blow to hear,
As will a Chestnut in a Farmers fire.
Tush, tush, fear boys with bugs.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: For he fears none.

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.l: Hortensio hark:
This Gentleman is happily arrived,
My mind presumes for his own good, and yours.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I promised we would be Contributors,
And bear his charge of wooing whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Gremio.
sp.l: And so we will, provided that he win her.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
Gentlemen God save you. If I may be bold
Tell me I beseech you, which is the readiest way
To the house of Seignior Baptista Minola?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p:
He that has the two fair daughters: is it he you
mean?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Even he Biondello.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Hark you sir, you mean not her to---

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Perhaps him and her sir, what have you to do?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Not her that chides sir, at any hand I pray.

sp.speaker: Tranio.
sp.l: I love no chiders sir: Biondello, let us away.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: Well begun Tranio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Sir, a word ere you go:
Are you a suitor to the Maid you talk of, yea or no?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And if I be sir, is it any offence?

sp.speaker: Gremio.
sp.l: No: if without more words you will get you
hence.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why sir, I pray are not the streets as free
For me, as for you?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: But so is not she.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: For what reason I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: For this reason if you will know,
That she is the choice love of Seignior Gremio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That she is the chosen of seignior Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Softly my Masters: If you be Gentlemen
Do me this right: hear me with patience.
Baptista is a noble Gentleman,
To whom my Father is not all unknown,
And were his daughter fairer than she is,
She may more suitors have, and me for one.
Fair Lædaes daughter had a thousand wooers,
Then well one more may fair Bianca have;
And so she shall: Lucentio shall make one,
Though Paris came, in hope to speed alone.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: What, this Gentleman will out-talk us all.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir give him head, I know he will prove a Jade.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Sir, let me be so bold as ask you,
Did you yet ever see Baptistas daughter?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No sir, but hear I do that he hath two:
The one, as famous for a scolding tongue,
As is the other, for beauteous modesty.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Sir, sir, the first is for me, let her go by.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Yea, leave that labour to great Hercules,
And let it be more than Alcides twelve.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Sir understand you this of me (insooth)
The youngest daughter whom you hearken for,
Her father keeps from all access of suitors,
And will not promise her to any man,
Until the elder sister first be wed.
The younger then is free, and not before.

sp.speaker: Tranio.
sp.l: If it be so sir, that you are the man
Must steed us all, and me amongst the rest:
And if you break the ice, and do this seek,
Achieve the elder: set the younger free,
For our access, whose hap shall be to have her,
will not so graceless be, to be ingrate.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Sir you say well, and well you do conceive,
And since you do profess to be a suitor,
You must as we do, gratify this Gentleman,
To whom we all rest generally beholding.

sp.speaker: Tranio.
sp.l: Sir, I shall not be slack, in sign whereof,
Please ye we may contrive this afternoon,
And quaff carouses to our Mistress health,
And do as adversaries do in law,
Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.

sp.speaker: Gru.Bion.
sp.l: O excellent motion: fellows let us be gon.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The motions good indeed, and be it so,
Petruchio, I shall be your Been venuto.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Good sister wrong me not, nor wrong yourself,
To make a bondmaid and a slave of me,
That I disdain: but for these other goods,
Unbind my hands, I will pull them off myself,
Yea all my raiment, to my petticoat,
Or what you will command me, will I do,
So well I know my duty to my elders.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Of all thy suitors here I charge tell
Whom thou lovest best: see thou dissemble not.

sp.speaker: Bianca.
sp.l: Believe me sister, of all the men alive,
I never yet beheld that special face,
Which I could fancy, more than any other.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Minion thou liest: Is it not Hortensio?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: If you affect him sister, here I swear
I will plead for you myself, but you shall have him.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: O then belike you fancy riches more,
You will have Gremio to keep you fair.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Is it for him you do envy me so?
Nay then you jest, and now I well perceive
You have but jested with me all this while:
I prithee sister Kate, untie my hands.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: If that be jest, then all the rest was so.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Why how now Dame, whence grows this insolence?
Bianca stand aside, poor girl she weeps:
Go ply thy Needle, meddle not with her.
For shame thou Hilding of a devilish spirit,
Why dost thou wrong her, that did ne'er wrong thee?
When did she cross thee with a bitter word?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Her silence flouts me, and I will be revenged.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: What in my sight? Bianca get thee in.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: What will you not suffer me: Nay now I see
She is your treasure, she must have a husband,
I must dance bare-foot on her wedding day,
And for your love to her, lead Apes in hell.
Talk not to me, I will go sit and weep,
Till I can find occasion of revenge.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Was ever Gentleman thus grieved as I?
But who comes here.

div2.stage: Enter Gremio, Lucentio, in the habit of a meane man, Petruchio with Tranio, with his boy bearing a Lute and Bookes.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Good morrow neighbour Baptista.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p:
Good morrow neighbour Gremio: God save
you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: And you good sir: pray have you not a daughter, called Katerina, fair and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I have a daughter sir, called Katerina.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: You are too blunt, go to it orderly.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You wrong me seignior Gremio, give me leave.
I am a Gentleman of Verona sir,
That hearing of her beauty, and her wit,
Her affability and bashful modesty:
Her wondrous qualities, and mild behaviour,
Am bold to show myself a forward guest
Within your house, to make mine eye the witness
Of that report, which I so oft have heard,
And for an entrance to my entertainment,
I do present you with a man of mine
Cunning in Music, and the Mathematics,
To instruct her fully in those sciences,
Whereof I know she is not ignorant,
Accept of him, or else you do me wrong,
His name is Litio, born in Mantua.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: You are welcome sir, and he for your good sake.
But for my daughter Katerine, this I know,
She is not for your turn, the more my grief.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I see you do not mean to part with her,
Or else you like not of my company.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Mistake me not, I speak but as I find,
Whence are you sir? What may I call your name.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Petruchio is my name, Antonio's son,
A man well known throughout all Italy.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I know him well: you are welcome for his sake.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Saving your tale Petruchio, I pray let us that are
poor petitioners speak too? Bacare, you are marvelous forward.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O, Pardon me seignior Gremio, I would fain be
doing.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: I doubt it not sir. But you will curse
Your wooing neighbours: this is a gift
sp.p:
Very grateful, I am sure of it, to express
The like kindness myself, that have been
More kindly beholding to you than any:
Freely give unto this young Scholar, that hath
Been long studying at Rhemes, as cunning
In Greek, Latin, and other Languages,
As the other in Music and Mathematics:
His name is Cambio: pray accept his service.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p:
A thousand thanks seignior Gremio:
Welcome good Cambio. But gentle sir,
Methinks you walk like a stranger,
May I be so bold, to know the cause of your coming?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, the boldness is mine own,
That being a stranger in this City here,
Do make myself as tutor to your daughter,
Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous:
Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me,
In the preferment of the eldest sister.
This liberty is all that I request,
That upon knowledge of my Parentage,
I may have welcome amongst the rest that woo,
And free access and favour as the rest.
And toward the education of your daughters:
I here bestow a simple instrument,
And this small packet of Greek and Latin books:
If you accept them, then their worth is great:

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Lucentio is your name, of whence I pray.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Of Pisa sir, son to Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: A mighty man of Pisa by report,
I know him well: you are very welcome sir:
Take you the Lute, and you the set of books,
You shall go see your Pupils presently.
Holla, within.
Sirrah, lead these Gentlemen
To my daughters, and tell them both
These are their Tutors, bid them use them well,
We will go walk a little in the Orchard,
And then to dinner: you are passing welcome,
And so I pray you all to think yourselves.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Seignior Baptista, my business asketh haste,
And every day I cannot come to woo,
You knew my father well, and in him me,
Left solely heir to all his Lands and goods,
Which I have bettered rather than decreased,
Then tell me, if I get your daughters love,
What dowry shall I have with her to wife.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: After my death, the one half of my Lands,
And in possession twenty thousand Crowns.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: And for that dowry, I will assure her of
Her widowhood, be it that she survive me
In all my Lands and Leases whatsoever,
Let specialities be therefore drawn between us,
That covenants may be kept on either hand.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Aye, when the special thing is well obtained,
That is her love: for that is all in all.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why that is nothing: for I tell you father,
I am as peremptory as she proud minded:
And where two raging fires meet together,
They do consume the thing that feeds their fury.
Though little fire grows great with little wind,
yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all:
So I to her, and so she yields to me,
For I am rough, and woo not like a babe.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed:
But be thou armed for some unhappy words.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Aye to the proof, as Mountains are for winds,
That shakes not, though they blow perpetually.

div2.stage: Enter Hortensio with his head broke.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: How now my friend, why dost thou look so
pale?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: For fear I promise you, if I look pale.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: What, will my daughter prove a good Musician?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I think she will sooner prove a soldier,
Iron may hold with her, but never Lutes.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Why then thou canst not break her to the Lute?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why no, for she hath broke the Lute to me:
I did but tell her she mistook her frets,
And bowed her hand to teach her fingering,
When (with a most impatient devilish spirit)
Frets call you these? (quoth she) I will fume with them:
And with that word she stroke me on the head,
And through the instrument my pate made way,
And there I stood amazed for a while,
As on a Pillory, looking through the Lute,
While she did call me Rascal, Fiddler,
And twangling Iacke, with twenty such vild terms,
As had she studied to misuse me so.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now by the world, it is a lusty Wench,
I love her ten times more than ere I did,
O how I long to have some chat with her.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Well go with me, and be not so discomfited.
Proceed in practise with my younger daughter,
She is apt to learn, and thankful for good turns:
Seignior Petruchio, will you go with us,
Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I pray you do. I will attend her here,
And woo her with some spirit when she comes,
Say that she rail, why then I will tell her plain,
She sings as sweetly as a Nightingale:
Say that she frown, I will say she looks as clear
As morning Roses newly washed with dew:
Say she be mute, and will not speak a word,
Then I will commend her volubility,
And say she uttereth piercing eloquence:
If she do bid me pack, I will give her thanks,
As though she bid me stay by her a week:
If she deny to wed, I will crave the day
When I shall ask the banes, and when be married.
But here she comes, and now Petruchio speak.
Good morrow Kate, for that is your name I hear.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Well have you heard, but something hard of
hearing:
They call me Katerine, that do talk of me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You lie i'faith, for you are called plain Kate,
And bony Kate, and sometimes Kate the cursed:
But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom,
Kate of Kate-hall, my super dainty Kate,
For dainties are all Kates, and therefore Kate
Take this of me, Kate of my consolation,
Hearing thy mildness praised in every Town,
Thy vertues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded,
Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs,
Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Moved, in good time, let him that moved you
Remove you hence: I knew you at the first
You were a movable.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why, what is a movable?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: A joined stool.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Thou hast hit it: come sit on me.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: No such Jade as you, if me you mean.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Alas good Kate, I will not burthen thee,
For knowing thee to be but young and light.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Too light for such a swain as you to catch,
And yet as heavy as my weight should be.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Should be, should: buzz.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Well taken, and like a buzzard.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O slow-winged Turtle, shall a buzzard take thee?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Aye for a Turtle, as he takes a buzzard.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Come, come you Wasp, i'faith you are too
angry.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: My remedy is then to pluck it out.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Aye, if the fool could find it where it lies.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Who knows not where a Wasp does wear
his sting? In his tail.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: In his tongue?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Whose tongue.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Yours if you talk of tales, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What with my tongue in your tail.
Nay, come again, good Kate, I am a Gentleman,

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: That I will try.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I swear I will cuff you, if you strike again.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: So may you loose your arms,
If you strike me, you are no Gentleman,
And if no Gentleman, why then no arms.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: A Herald Kate? O put me in thy books.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: What is your Crest, a Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: A combless Cock, so Kate will be my Hen.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: No Cock of mine, you crow too like a craven

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay come Kate, come: you must not look so
sour.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: It is my fashion when I see a Crab.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why here is no crab, and therefore look not
sour.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: There is, there is.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Then show it me.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Had I a glass, I would.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What, you mean my face.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Well aimed of such a young one.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now by S. George I am too young for you.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Yet you are withered.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It is with cares.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I care not.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay hear you Kate. Insooth you scape not so.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I chafe you if I tarry. Let me go.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No, not a whit, I find you passing gentle:
It was told me you were rough, and coy, and sullen,
And now I find report a very liar:
For thou art pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous,
But slow in speech: yet sweet as spring-time flowers.
Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look a sconce,
Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will,
Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk:
But thou with mildness entertainest thy wooers,
With gentle conference, soft, and affable.
Why does the world report that Kate doth limp?
O slanderous world: Kate like the hazel twig
Is straight, and slender, and as brown in hue
As hazel nuts, and sweeter than the kernels:
O let me see thee walk: thou dost not halt.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Go fool, and whom thou keepest command.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Did ever Dian so become a Grove
As Kate this chamber with her princely gate:
O be thou Dian, and let her be Kate,
And then let Kate be chaste, and Dian sportful.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Where did you study all this goodly speech?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: It is extempore, from my mother wit.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: A witty mother, witless else her son.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Am I not wise?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Yes, keep you warm.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Marry so I mean sweet Katherine in thy bed:
And therefore setting all this chat aside,
Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented
That you shall be my wife; your dowry greed on,
And will you, nill you, I will marry you.
Now Kate, I am a husband for your turn,
For by this light, whereby I see thy beauty,
Thy beauty that doth make me like thee well,
Thou must be married to no man but me,
For I am he am born to tame you Kate,
And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate
Conformable as other household Kates:
Here comes your father, never make denial,
I must, and will have Katherine to my wife.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Now Seignior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: How but well sir? how but well?
It were impossible I should speed amiss.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Why how now daughter Katherine, in your dumps?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Call you me daughter? now I promise you
You have showed a tender fatherly regard,
To wish me wed to one half Lunatic,
A mad-cap ruffian, and a swearing Iacke,
That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Father, it is thus, yourself and all the world
That talked of her, have talked amiss of her:
If she be cursed, it is for policy,
For she is not froward, but modest as the Dove,
She is not hot, but temperate as the morn,
For patience she will prove a second Grissell,
And Roman Lucrece for her chastity:
And to conclude, we have greed so well together,
That upon sunday is the wedding day.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I will see thee hanged on sunday first.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Hark Petruchio, she says she will see thee hanged first.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Is this your speeding? nay then goodnight our part.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Be patient gentlemen, I choose her for myself,
If she and I be pleased, what is that to you?
It is bargained twixt us twain being alone,
That she shall still be cursed in company.
I tell you it is incredible to believe
How much she loves me: O the kindest Kate,
She hung about my neck, and kiss on kiss
She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath,
That in a twinkle she won me to her love.
O you are novices, it is a world to see
How tame when men and women are alone,
A meacock wretch can make the cursedest shrew:
Give me thy hand Kate, I will unto Venice
To buy apparel against the wedding day;
Provide the feast father, and bid the guests,
I will be sure my Katherine shall be fine.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I know not what to say, but give me your hands,
God send you joy, Petruchio, it is a match.

sp.speaker: Gre.Tra.
sp.l: Amen say we, we will be witnesses.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Father, and wife, and gentlemen adieu,
I will to Venice, sunday comes apace,
We will have rings, and things, and fine array,
And kiss me Kate, we will be married on sunday.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Was ever match clapped up so suddenly?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Faith Gentlemen now I play a merchants part,
And venture madly on a desperate Mart.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: It was a commodity lay fretting by you,
It will bring you gain, or perish on the seas.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: The gain I seek, is quiet me the match.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch:
But now Baptista, to your younger daughter,
Now is the day we long have looked for,
I am your neighbour, and was suitor first.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And I am one that love Bianca more
Than words can witness, or your thoughts can guess.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Youngling thou canst not love so dear as I.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Gray-beard thy love doth freeze.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: But thine doth fry,
Skipper stand back, it is age that nourisheth.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But youth in Ladies eyes that florisheth.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Content you gentlemen, I will compound this strife
It is deeds must win the prize, and he of both
That can assure my daughter greatest dower,
Shall have my Biancas love.
Say seignior Gremio, what can you assure her?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: First, as you know, my house within the City
Is richly furnished with plate and gold,
Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands:
My hangings all of tirian tapestry:
In Ivory coffers I have stuffed my crowns:
In Cypress chests my arras counterpoints,
Costly apparel, tents, and Canopies,
Fine Linen, Turky cushions bossed with pearl,
Vallens of Venice gold, in needle work:
Pewter and brass, and all things that belongs
To house or house-keeping: then at my farm
I have a hundred milch-kine to the pale,
Six score fat Oxen standing in my stalls,
And all things answerable to this portion.
Myself am struck in years I must confess,
And if I die tomorrow this is hers,
If whilst I live she will be only mine.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That only came well in: sir, list to me,
I am my fathers heir and only son,
If I may have your daughter to my wife,
I will leave her houses three or four as good
Within rich Pisa walls, as any one
Old Seignior Gremio has in Padua,
Besides, two thousand Ducats by the year
Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointer.
What, have I pinched you Seignior Gremio?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Two thousand Ducats by the year of land,
My Land amounts not to so much in all:
That she shall have, besides an Argosy
That now is lying in Marcellus road:
What, have I choked you with an Argosy?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Gremio, it is known my father hath no less
Than three great Argosies, besides two Galleasses
And twelve tight Galleys, these I will assure her,
And twice as much what ere thou offerest next.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Nay, I have offered all, I have no more,
And she can have no more than all I have,
If you like me, she shall have me and mine.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why then the maid is mine from all the world
By your firm promise, Gremio is out-vied.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I must confess your offer is the best,
And let your father make her the assurance,
She is your own, else you must pardon me:
If you should die before him, where is her dower?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That is but a cavil: he is old, I young.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: And may not young men die as well as old?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Well gentlemen, I am thus resolved,
On sunday next, you know
My daughter Katherine is to be married:
Now on the sunday following, shall Bianca
Be Bride to you, if you make this assurance:
If not, to Seignior Gremio:
And so I take my leave, and thank you both.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Adieu good neighbour: now I fear thee not:
Sirrah, young gamester, your father were a fool
To give thee all, and in his waning age
Set foot under thy table: tut, a toy,
An old Italian fox is not so kind my boy.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A vengeance on your crafty withered hide,
Yet I have faced it with a card of ten:
It is in my head to do my master good:
I see no reason but supposed Lucentio
Must get a father, called supposed Uincentio,
And that is a wonder: fathers commonly
Do get their children: but in this case of wooing,
A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Fiddler forbear, you grow too forward Sir,
Have you so soon forgot the entertainment
Her sister Katherine welcomed you withal.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: But wrangling pedant, this is
The patroness of heavenly harmony:
Then give me leave to have prerogative,
And when in Music we have spent an hour,
Your Lecture shall have leisure for as much.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Preposterous Ass that never read so far,
To know the cause why music was ordained:
Was it not to refresh the mind of man
After his studies, or his usual pain?
Then give me leave to read Philosophy,
And while I pause, serve in your harmony.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.

sp.speaker: Bianc.
sp.l: Why gentlemen, you do me double wrong,
To strive for that which resteth in my choice:
I am no breeching scholar in the schools,
I will not be tied to hours, nor pointed times,
But learn my Lessons as I please myself,
And to cut off all strife: here sit we down,
Take you your instrument, play you the whiles,
His Lecture will be done ere you have tuned.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: You will leave his Lecture when I am in tune?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That will be never, tune your instrument.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Where left we last?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Here Madam: Hic Ibat Simois, hic est sigeria tellus, hic steterat Priami regia Celsa senis.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Conster them.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Hic Ibat, as I told you before, Simois, I am Lucentio, hic est, son unto Vincentio of Pisa, Sigeria tellus, disguised thus to get your love, hic steterat, and that
Lucentio that comes awooing, priami, is my man Tranio, regia, bearing my port, celsa senis that we might beguile the old Pantaloon.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Madam, my Instrument's in tune.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Let us hear, O fie, the treble jars.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Spit in the hole man, and tune again.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p:
Now let me see if I can conster it. Hic ibat simois, I know you not, hic est sigeria tellus, I trust you not,
hic staterat priami, take heed he hear us not, regia presume not, Celsa senis, despair not.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Madam, it is now in tune.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All but the base.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: The base is right, it is the base knave that jars.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How fiery and forward our Pedant is,
Now for my life the knave doth court my love,
Pedascule, I will watch you better yet:
In time I may believe, yet I mistrust.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Mistrust it not, for sure Aeacides
Was Aiax called so from his grandfather.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I must believe my master, else I promise you,
I should be arguing still upon that doubt,
But let it rest, now Litio to you:
Good master take it not unkindly pray
That I have been thus pleasant with you both.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: You may go walk, and give me leave a while,
My Lessons make no music in three parts.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are you so formal sir, well I must wait
And watch withal, for but I be deceived,
Our fine Musician groweth amorous.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Madam, before you touch the instrument,
To learn the order of my fingering,
I must begin with rudiments of Art,
To teach you gamut in a briefer sort,
More pleasant, pithy, and effectual,
Than hath been taught by any of my trade,
And there it is in writing fairly drawn.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Why, I am past my gamut long ago.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yet read the gamut of Hortentio.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Gamut I am, the ground of all accord:
Are, to plead Hortensio's passion:
Beeme, Bianca take him for thy Lord
Cfavt, that loves with all affection:
D solre, one Clef, two notes have I,
Ela mi, show pity or I die,
Call you this gamut? tut I like it not,
Old fashions please me best, I am not so nice
To charge true rules for old inventions.

sp.speaker: Nicke.
sp.l: Mistress, your father prays you leave your books,
And help to dress your sisters chamber up,
You know tomorrow is the wedding day.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Farewell sweet masters both, I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Faith Mistress then I have no cause to stay.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But I have cause to pry into this pedant,
Methinks he looks as though he were in love:
Yet if thy thoughts Bianca be so humble
To cast thy wandering eyes on every stale:
Seize thee that List, if once I find thee ranging,
Hortensio will be quit with thee by changing.

div2.stage: Enter Baptista, Gremio, Tranio, Katherine, Bianca, and others, attendants.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Seignior Lucentio, this is the pointed day
That Katherine and Petruchio should be married,
And yet we hear not of our son-in-law:
What will be said, what mockery will it be?
To want the Bridegroom when the Priest attends
To speak the ceremonial rites of marriage?
What says Lucentio to this shame of ours?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: No shame but mine, I must forsooth be forced
To give my hand opposed against my heart
Unto a mad-brain rudesby, full of spleen,
Who wooed in haste, and means to wed at leisure:
I told you I, he was a frantic fool,
Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behaviour,
And to be noted for a merry man;
He will woo a thousand, point the day of marriage,
Make friends, invite, and proclaim the banes,
Yet never means to wed where he hath wooed:
Now must the world point at poor Katherine,
And say, lo, there is mad Petruchio's wife
If it would please him come and marry her.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Patience good Katherine and Baptista too,
Upon my life Petruchio means but well,
What ever fortune stays him from his word,
Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise,
Though he be merry, yet withal he is honest.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Would Katherine had never seen him though.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Go girl, I cannot blame thee now to weep,
For such an injury would vex a very saint,
Much more a shrew of impatient humour.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p:
Master, master, news, and such news as you
never heard of,

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Is it new and old too? how may that be?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: Why, is it not news to heard of Petruchio's coming?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Is he come?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: Why no sir.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: He is coming.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: When will he be here?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: When he stands where I am, and sees you there.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: But say, what to thine old news?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p:
Why Petruchio is coming, in a new hat and
an old jerkin, a pair of old breeches thrice turned; a
pair of boots that have been candle-cases, one buckled, another laced: an old rusty sword taken out of the
Town Armoury, with a broken hilt, and chapless: with
two broken points: his horse hipped with an old mothy saddle, and stirrups of no kindred: besides possessed
with the glanders, and like to mose in the chine, troubled with the Lampasse, infected with the fashions, full
of Windegalls, sped with Spavins, rayed with the Yellows, past cure of the Fives, stark spoiled with the
Staggers, begnawn with the Bots, Weighed in the back,
and shoulder-shotten, near legged before, and with a
half-checked Bit,and a headstall of sheeps leather, which
being restrained to keep him from stumbling, hath been
often burst, and now repaired with knots: one girth six
times pieced, and a woman's Crupper of velour, which
hath two letters for her name, fairly set down in studs,
and here and there pieced with pack-thread.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Who comes with him?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p:
O sir, his Lackey, for all the world Caparisoned like the horse: with a linen stock on one leg, and
a kersey boot-hose on the other, gartered with a red and
blue list; an old hat, and the humour of forty fancies pricked
in it for a feather: a monster, a very monster in apparel,
and not like a Christian foot-boy, or a gentleman's Lackey.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: It is some odd humour pricks him to this fashion,
Yet oftentimes he goes but mean apparelled.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I am glad he is come, howsoever he comes.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: Why sir, he comes not.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Didst thou not say he comes?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: Who, that Petruchio came?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Aye, that Petruchio came.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: No sir, I say his horse comes with him on his back.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Why that is all one.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p:
Nay by S.Iamy, I hold you a penny, a horse and
a man is more than one, and yet not many.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Come, where be these gallants? who is at home?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: You are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: And yet I come not well.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: And yet you halt not.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Not so well apparelled as I wish you were.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Were it better I should rush in thus:
But where is Kate? where is my lovely Bride?
How does my father? gentles methinks you frown,
And wherefore gaze this goodly company,
As if they saw some wondrous monument,
Some Comet, or unusual prodigy?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Why sir, you know this is your wedding day:
First were we sad, fearing you would not come,
Now sadder that you come so unprovided:
Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate,
An eye-sore to our solemn festival.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And tell us what occasion of import
Hath all so long detained you from your wife,
And sent you hither so unlike your self?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Tedious it were to tell, and harsh to hear,
Sufficeth I am come to keep my word,
Though in some part enforced to digress,
Which at more leisure I will so excuse,
As you shall well be satisfied with all.
But where is Kate? I stay too long from her,
The morning wears, it is time we were at Church.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: See not your Bride in these unreverent robes,
Go to my chamber, put on clothes of mine.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Not I, believe me, thus I will visit her.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: But thus I trust you will not marry her.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Good sooth even thus: therefore have done with words,
To me she is married, not unto my clothes:
Could I repair what she will wear in me,
As I can change these poor accoutrements,
It were well for Kate, and better for myself.
But what a fool am I to chat with you,
When I should bid good morrow to my Bride?
And seal the title with a lovely kiss.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: He hath some meaning in his mad attire,
We will persuade him be it possible,
To put on better ere he go to Church.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I will after him, and see the event of this.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But sir, Love concerneth us to add
Her fathers liking, which to bring to pass
As before imparted to your worship,
I am to get a man what ere he be,
It skills not much, we will fit him to our turn,
And he shall be Vincentio of Pisa,
And make assurance here in Padua
Of greater sums than I have promised,
So shall you quietly enjoy your hope,
And marry sweet Bianca with consent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Were it not that my fellow schoolmaster
Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly:
It were good methinks to steal our marriage,
Which once performed, let all the world say no,
I will keep mine own despite of all the world.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That by degrees we mean to look into,
And watch our vantage in this business,
We will over-reach the grey-beard Gremio,
The narrow prying father Minola,
The quaint Musician, amorous Litio,
All for my Masters sake Lucentio.
Seignior Gremio, came you from the Church?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: As willingly as ere I came from school.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And is the Bride and Bridegroom coming home?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: A bridegroom say you? it is a groom indeed,
A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Curseder than she, why it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Why he is a devil, a devil, a very fiend.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why she is a devil, a devil, the devils dam.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Tut, she is a Lamb, a Dove, a fool to him:
I will tell you sir Lucentio; when the Priest
Should ask if Katherine should be his wife,
Aye, by gog's wounds quoth he, and swore so loud,
That all amazed the Priest let fall the book,
And as he stooped again to take it up,
This mad-brained bridegroom took him such a cuff,
That down fell Priest and book, and book and Priest,
Now take them up quoth he, if any list.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What said the wench when he rose again?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Trembled and shook: for why, he stamped and
swore, as if the Vicar meant to cozen him: but after many ceremonies done, he calls for wine, a health quoth
he, as if he had been aboard carousing to his Mates after a storm, quaffed off the Muscatel, and threw the sops
all in the Sextons face: having no other reason, but that
his beard grew thin and hungerly, and seemed to ask
him sops as he was drinking: This done, he took the
Bride about the neck, and kissed her lips with such a clamorous smack, that at the parting all the Church did
echo: and I seeing this, came thence for very shame, and
after me I know the rout is coming, such a mad marriage never was before: hark, hark, I hear the minstrels play.

div2.stage: Enter Petruchio, Kate, Bianca, Hortensio, Baptista.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for your pains,
I know you think to dine with me today,
And have prepared great store of wedding cheer,
But so it is, my haste doth call me hence,
And therefore here I mean to take my leave.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Is it possible you will away tonight?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I must away today before night come,
Make it no wonder: if you knew my business,
You would entreat me rather go than stay:
And honest company, I thank you all,
That have beheld me give away myself
To this most patient, sweet, and virtuous wife,
Dine with my father, drink a health to me,
For I must hence, and farewell to you all.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It may not be.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Let me entreat you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Let me entreat you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am content.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Are you content to stay?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am content you shall entreat me stay,
But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Now if you love me stay.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Grumio, my horse.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Aye sir, they be ready, the Oats have eaten the
horses.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Nay then,
Do what thou canst, I will not go today,
No, nor tomorrow, not till I please myself,
The door is open sir, there lies your way,
You may be jogging whiles your boots are green:
For me, I will not be gone till I please myself,
It is like you will prove a jolly surly groom,
That take it on you at the first so roundly.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O Kate content thee, prithee be not angry.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: I will be angry, what hast thou to do?
Father, be quiet, he shall stay my leisure.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Aye marry sir, now it begins to work.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner,
I see a woman may be made a fool
If she had not a spirit to resist.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: They shall go forward Kate at thy command,
Obey the Bride you that attend on her.
Go to the feast, revel and domineer,
Carouse full measure to her maiden-head,
Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves:
But for my bonny Kate, she must with me:
Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret,
I will be master of what is mine own,
She is my goods, my chattels, she is my house,
My household-stuff, my field, my barn,
My horse, my ox, my ass, my anything,
And here she stands, touch her whoever dare,
I will bring mine action on the proudest he
That stops my way in Padua: Grumio
Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves,
Rescue thy Mistress if thou be a man:
Fear not sweet wench, they shall not touch thee Kate,
I will buckler thee against a Million.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Of all mad matches never was the like.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Mistress, what is your opinion of your sister?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: That being mad herself, she is madly mated.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: I warrant him Petruchio is Kated.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Neighbours and friends, though Bride and Bride-groom wants
For to supply the places at the table,
You know there wants no junkets at the feast:
Lucentio, you shall supply the Bridegrooms place,
And let Bianca take her sisters room.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Shall sweet Bianca practise how to bride it?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: She shall Lucentio: come gentlemen let us go.

sp.speaker: Gru.:
sp.p:
Fie, fie on all tired Jades, on all mad Masters, and
all foul ways: was ever man so beaten? was ever man
so raide? was ever man so weary? I am sent before to
make a fire, and they are coming after to warm them:
now were not I a little pot, and soon hot; my very lips
might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my
mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire
to thaw me, but I with blowing the fire shall warm myself:
for considering the weather, a taller man than I
will take cold: Holla, hoa Curtis.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Who is that calls so coldly?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
A piece of Ice: if thou doubt it, thou mayst
slide from my shoulder to my heel, with no
greater a run but my head and my neck. A fire good
Curtis.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Is my master and his wife coming Grumio?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
O Aye Curtis Aye, and therefore fire, fire, cast on no
water.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Is she so hot a shrew as she is reported.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
She was good Curtis before this frost: but thou
knowest winter tames man, woman, and beast: for it
hath tamed my old master, and my new mistress, and myself
fellow Curtis.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Away you three inch fool, I am no beast.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Am I but three inches? Why thy horn is a foot
and so long am I at the least. But wilt thou make a fire,
or shall I complain on thee to our mistress, whose hand
