(she being now at hand) thou shalt soon feele, to thy
cold comfort, for being slow in thy hot office.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
I prithee good Grumio, tell me, how goes the
world?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
A cold world Curtis in every office but thine, and
therefore fire: do thy duty, and have thy duty, for my
Master and mistress are almost frozen to death.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
There is fire ready, and therefore good Grumio
the news.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Why Iacke boy, ho boy, and as much news as
wilt thou.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come, you are so full of cony catching.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Why therefore fire, for I have caught extreme
cold. Where is the Cook, is supper ready, the house
trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept, the serving-men
in their new fustian, the white stockings, and every officer his wedding garment on? Be the Iackes fair within, the Gils fair without, the Carpets laid, and everything
in order?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: All ready: and therefore I pray thee news.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: First know my horse is tired, my master and mistress fallen out.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Out of their saddles into the dirt, and thereby
hangs a tale.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Let us have it good Grumio.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Lend thine ear.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: This it is to feele a tale, not to hear a tale.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
And therefore it is called a sensible tale: and this
Cuff was but to knock at your ear, and beseech listening: now I begin, Inprimis we came down a foul
hill, my Master riding behind my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Both of one horse?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: What is that to thee?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Why a horse.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crossed me,
thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell, and she under her horse: thou shouldst have heard in how miry a
place, how she was bemoiled, how he left her with the
horse upon her, how he beat me because her horse stumbled, how she waded through the dirt to pluck him off
me: how he swore, how she prayed, that never prayed before: how I cried, how the horses ran away, how her
bridle was burst: how I lost my crupper, with many
things of worthy memory, which now shall die in oblivion, and thou return unexperienced to thy grave.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: By this reckoning he is more shrew than she.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Aye, and that thou and the proudest of you all shall
find when he comes home. But what talk I of this?
Call forth Nathaniel, Ioseph, Nicholas, Phillip, Walter, Sugersop and the rest: let their heads be slickly combed,
their blue coats brushed, and their garters of an indifferent knit, let them curtsy with their left legs, and not
presume to touch a hair of my Masters horsetail, till
they kiss their hands. Are they all ready?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: They are.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Call them forth.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
Do you hear ho? you must meet my master
to countenance my mistress.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Why she hath a face of her own.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Who knows not that?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Thou it seems, that calls for company to countenance her.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I call them forth to credit her.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Why she comes to borrow nothing of them.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.p: Welcome home Grumio.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How now Grumio.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: What Grumio.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Fellow Grumio.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.p: How now old lad.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Welcome you: how now you: what you: fellow you: and thus much for greeting. Now my spruce
companions, is all ready, and all things neat?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.p: All things is ready, how near is our master?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p:
Even at hand, alighted by this: and therefore be
not--- Cocks passion, silence, I hear my master.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Where be these knaves? What no man at door
To hold my stirrup, nor to take my horse?
Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Phillip.

sp.speaker: All ser.
sp.l: Here, here sir, here sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Here sir, here sir, here sir, here sir.
You logger-headed and unpolished grooms:
What? no attendance? no regard? no duty?
Where is the foolish knave I sent before?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Here sir, as foolish as I was before.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You peasant, swain, you whoreson malt-horse drudge
Did I not bid thee meet me in the Park,
And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?

sp.speaker: Grumio.
sp.l: Nathaniels coat sir was not fully made,
And Gabrels pumps were all unpinked in the heel:
There was no Link to colour Peters hat,
And Walters dagger was not come from sheathing:
There were none fine, but Adam, Rafe, and Gregory,
The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly,
Yet as they are, here are they come to meet you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Go rascals, go, and fetch my supper in.
Where is the life that late I led?
sp.p:
Where are those? Sit down Kate,
And welcome. Soud, soud, soud, soud.
sp.l: Why when I say? Nay good sweet Kate be merry.
Off with my boots, you rogues: you villains, when?
It was the Friar of Orders gray,
As he forth walked on his way.
Out you rogue, you pluck my foot awry,
Take that, and mend the plucking of the other.
Be merry Kate: Some water here: what hoa.
Where is my Spaniel Troilus? Sirrah, get you hence,
And bid my cozen Ferdinand come hither:
One Kate that you must kiss, and be acquainted with.
Where are my Slippers? Shall I have some water?
Come Kate and wash,and welcome heartily:
you whoreson villain, will you let it fall?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Patience I pray you, it was a fault unwilling.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: A whoreson beetle-headed flap-eared knave:
Come Kate sit down, I know you have a stomach,
Will you give thanks, sweet Kate, or else shall I?
What is this, Mutton?

sp.speaker: 1.Ser.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It is burnt, and so is all the meat:
What dogs are these? Where is the rascal Cook?
How durst you villains bring it from the dresser
And serve it thus to me that love it not?
There, take it to you, trenchers, cups, and all:
You heedless jolt-heads, and unmannered slaves.
What, do you grumble? I will be with you straight.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I pray you husband be not so disquiet,
The meat was well, if you were so contented.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I tell thee Kate, it was burnt and dried away,
And I expressly am forbid to touch it:
For it engenders choler, planteth anger,
And better it were that both of us did fast,
Since of ourselves, ourselves are choleric,
Then feed it with such over-roasted flesh:
Be patient, tomorrow it shall be mended,
And for this night we will fast for company.
Come I will bring thee to thy Bridal chamber.

sp.speaker: Nath.
sp.p: Peter didst ever see the like.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: He kills her in her own humour.

sp.speaker: Grumio.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: In her chamber, making a sermon of continence to her, and rails, and swears, and rates, that she
(poor soul) knows not which way to stand, to look,
to speak, and sits as one new risen from a dream. Away, away, for he is coming hither.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Thus have I politically begun my reign,
And it is my hope to end successfully:
My Falcon now is sharpe, and passing empty,
And till she stoop, she must not be full gorged,
For then she never looks upon her lure.
Another way I have to man my Haggard,
To make her come, and know her Keepers call:
That is, to watch her, as we watch these Kites,
That bait, and beat, and will not be obedient:
She eat no meat today, nor none shall eat.
Last night she slept not, nor tonight she shall not:
As with the meat, some undeserved fault
I will find about the making of the bed,
And here I will fling the pillow, there the bolster,
This way the Coverlet, another way the sheets:
Aye, and amid this hurly I intend,
That all is done in reverend care of her,
And in conclusion, she shall watch all night,
And if she chance to nod, I will rail and brawl,
And with the clamour keep her still awake:
This is a way to kill a Wife with kindness,
And thus I will curb her mad and headstrong humour:
He that knows better how to tame a shrew,
Now let him speak, it is charity to show.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Is it possible friend Lisio, that mistress Bianca
Doth fancy any other but Lucentio,
I tell you sir, she bears me fair in hand.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said,
Stand by, and mark the manner of his teaching.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Now Mistress, profit you in what you read?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: What Master read you first, resolve me that?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I read, that I profess the Art to love.

sp.speaker: Bian
sp.l: And may you prove sir Master of your Art.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: While you sweet dear prove Mistress of my
heart.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Quick proceeders marry, now tell me I pray,
you that durst swear that your Mistress Bianca
Loved me in the World so well as Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: O despiteful Love, unconstant womankind,
I tell thee Lisio this is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mistake no more, I am not Lisio,
Nor a Musician as I seem to be,
But one that scorn to live in this disguise,
For such a one as leaves a Gentleman,
And makes a God of such a Cullion;
Know sir, that I am called Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Seignior Hortensio, I have often heard
Of your entire affection to Bianca,
And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness,
I will with you, if you be so contented,
Forswear Bianca, and her love for ever.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: See how they kiss and court: Seignior Lucentio,
Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow
Never to woo her more, but do forswear her
As one unworthy all the former favours
That I have fondly flattered them withal.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And here I take the like unfeigned oath,
Never to marry with her, though she would entreat,
Fie on her, see how beastly she doth court him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn
For me, that I may surely keep mine oath.
I will be married to a wealthy Widow,
Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me,
As I have loved this proud disdainful Haggard,
And so farewell seignior Lucentio,
Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks
Shall win my love, and so I take my leave,
In resolution, as I swore before.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace,
As longeth to a Lovers blessed case:
Nay, I have taken you napping gentle Love,
And have forsworn you with Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Tranio you jest, but have you both forsworn
me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Mistress we have.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then we are rid of Lisio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I'faith he will have a lusty Widow now,
That shall be wooed, and wedded in a day.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: God give him joy.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Aye, and he will tame her.

sp.speaker: Bianca.
sp.l: He says so Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Faith he is gone unto the taming school.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: The taming school: what is there such a place?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Aye mistress, and Petruchio is the master,
That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long,
To tame a shrew, and charm her chattering tongue.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: O Master, master I have watched so long,
That I am dog-weary, but at last I spied
An ancient Angel coming down the hill,
Will serve the turn.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What is he Biondello?

sp.speaker: Bio.
sp.l: Master, a Marcantant, or a pedant,
I know not what, but formal in apparel,
In gate and countenance surely like a Father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And what of him Tranio?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: If he be credulous, and trust my tale,
I will make him glad to seem Vincentio,
And give assurance to Baptista Minola.
As if he were the right Uincentio.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Take me your love, and then let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And you sir, you are welcome,
Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Sir at the farthest for a week or two,
But then up farther, and as far as Rome,
And so to Tripolie, if God lend me life.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: What Countryman I pray?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Of Mantua.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Of Mantua Sir, marry God forbid,
And come to Padua careless of your life.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: My life sir? how I pray? for that goes hard.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: It is death for anyone in Mantua
To come to Padua, know you not the cause?
Your ships are staid at Venice, and the Duke
For private quarrel betwixt your Duke and him,
Hath published and proclaimed it openly:
It is marvel, but that you are but newly come,
you might have heard it else proclaimed about.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Alas sir, it is worse for me than so,
For I have bills for money by exchange
From Florence, and must here deliver them.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Well sir, to do you courtesy,
This will I do, and this I will advise you.
First tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Aye sir, in Pisa have I often been,
Pisa renowned for grave Citizens.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Among them know you one Vincentio?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I know him not, but I have heard of him:
A Merchant of incomparable wealth.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: He is my father sir, and sooth to say,
In countenance somewhat doth resemble you.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: As much as an apple doth an oyster, and all one.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: To save your life in this extremity,
This favour will I do you for his sake,
And think it not the worst of all your fortunes,
That you are like to Sir Vincentio.
His name and credit shall you undertake,
And in my house you shall be friendly lodged,
Look that you take upon you as you should,
you understand me sir: so shall you stay
Till you have done your business in the City:
If this be courtesy sir, accept of it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O sir I do, and will repute you ever
The patron of my life and liberty.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then go with me, to make the matter good,
This by the way I let you understand,
My father is here looked for every day,
To pass assurance of a dower in marriage
Betwixt me, and one Baptistas daughter here:
In all these circumstances I will instruct you,
Go with me to cloth you as becomes you.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: No, no forsooth I dare not for my life.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears.
What, did he marry me to famish me?
Beggars that come unto my fathers door,
Upon entreaty have a present alms,
If not, elsewhere they meet with charity:
But I, who never knew how to entreat,
Nor never needed that I should entreat,
Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep:
With oaths kept waking, and with brawling fed,
And that which spites me more than all these wants,
He does it under name of perfect love:
As who should say. if I should sleep or eat
It were deadly sickness, or else present death.
I prithee go, and get me some repast,
I care not what, so it be wholesome food.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: What say you to a Neats foot?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: It is passing good, I prithee let me have it.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I fear it is too choleric a meat.
How say you to a fat Tripe finely broiled?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I like it well, good Grumio fetch it me.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I cannot tell, I fear it is choleric.
What say you to a piece of Beef and Mustard?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: A dish that I do love to feed upon.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Aye, but the Mustard is too hot a little.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why then the Beef, and let the Mustard rest.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Nay then I will not, you shall have the Mustard
Or else you get no beef of Grumio.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Then both or one, or anything thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: Why then the Mustard without the beef.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Go get thee gone, thou false deluding slave,
That feedest me with the very name of meat.
Sorrow on thee, and all the pack of you
That triumph thus upon my misery:
Go get thee gone, I say.

div2.stage: Enter Petruchio, and Hortensio with meate.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: How fares my Kate, what sweeting all amort?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mistress, what cheer?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Faith as cold as can be.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pluck up thy spirits, look cheerfully upon me.
Here Love, thou seest how diligent I am,
To dress thy meat myself, and bring it thee.
I am sure sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.
What, not a word? Nay then, thou lovest it not:
And all my pains is sorted to no proof.
Here take away this dish.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I pray you let it stand.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The poorest service is repaid with thanks,
And so shall mine before you touch the meat.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Seignior Petruchio, fie you are too blame:
Come Mistress Kate, I will bear you company.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Eat it up all Hortensio, if thou lovest me:
Much good do it unto thy gentle heart:
Kate eat apace; and now my honey Love,
Will we return unto thy Fathers house,
And revel it as bravely as the best,
With silken coats and caps, and golden Rings,
With Ruffs and Cuffs, and Farthingales, and things:
With Scarfs, and Fans, and double change of bravery,
With Amber Bracelets, Beads, and all this knavery.
What hast thou dined? The Tailor stays thy leisure,
To deck thy body with his ruffling treasure.
Come Tailor, let us see these ornaments.
Lay forth the gown. What news with you sir?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Here is the cap your Worship did bespeak.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why this was moulded on a porringer,
A Velvet dish: Fie, fie, it is lewd and filthy,
Why it is a cockle or a walnut-shell,
A knack, a toy, a trick, a babies cap:
Away with it, come let me have a bigger.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I will have no bigger, this doth fit the time,
And Gentlewomen wear such caps as these.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: When you are gentle, you shall have one too,
And not till then.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That will not be in haste.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Why sir I trust I may have leave to speak,
And speak I will. I am no child, no babe,
Your betters have endured me say my mind,
And If you cannot, best you stop your ears.
My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,
Or else my heart concealing it will break,
And rather than it shall, I will be free,
Even to the uttermost as I please in words.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why thou sayst true, it is paltry cap,
A custard coffin, a bauble, a silken pie,
I love thee well in that thou likest it not.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Love me, or love me not, I like the cap,
And it I will have, or I will have none.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Thy gown, why Aye: come Tailor let us see it.
O mercy God, what masking stuff is here?
Whats this? a sleeve? it is like demi cannon,
What, up and down carved like an apple Tart?
Here is snip, and nip, and cut, and slish and slash,
Like to a Censor in a barbers shop:
Why what a devils name Tailor callest thou this?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I see she is like to have neither cap nor gown.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.l: You bid me make it orderly and well,
According to the fashion, and the time.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Marry and did: but if you be remembered,
I did not bid you mar it to the time.
Go hop me over every kennel home,
For you shall hop without my custom sir:
I will none of it; hence, make your best of it.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I never saw a better fashioned gown,
More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable:
Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why true, he means to make a puppet of thee.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p:
She says your Worship means to make a
puppet of her.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O monstrous arrogance:
Thou liest, thou thread, thou thimble,
Thou yard three quarters, half yard, quarter, nail,
Thou Flea, thou Nit, thou winter cricket thou:
Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread:
Away thou Rag, thou quantity, thou remnant,
Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard,
As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou livest:
I tell thee I, that thou hast marred her gown.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: Your worship is deceived, the gown is made
Just as my master had direction:
Grumio gave order how it should be done.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.l: I gave him no order, I gave him the stuff.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: But how did you desire it should be made?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Marry sir with needle and thread.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.l: But did you not request to have it cut?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Thou hast faced many things.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Face not me: thou hast braved many men,
brave not me; I will neither be faced nor braved. I say
unto thee, I bid thy Master cut out the gown, but I did
not bid him cut it to pieces. Ergo thou liest.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: Why here is the note of the fashion to testify.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Read it.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: The note lies in his throat if he say I said so.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: Inprimis, a loose bodied gown.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Master, if ever I said loose-bodied gown, sow
me in the skirts of it, and beat me to death with a bottom of brown thread: I said a gown.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.p: With a small compassed cape.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: I confess the cape.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.p: With a trunk sleeve.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: I confess two sleeves.

sp.speaker: Tai:
sp.p: The sleeves curiously cut.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Aye there is the villainy.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Error in the bill sir, error in the bill? I commanded
the sleeves should be cut out, and sowed up again, and
that I will prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p:
This is true that I say, and I had thee in place
where thou shouldst know it.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
I am for thee straight: take thou the bill, give
me thy meat-yard, and spare not me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
God-a-mercy Grumio, then he shall have no
odds.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well sir in brief the gown is not for me.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: You are in the right sir, it is for my mistress.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Go take it up unto thy masters use.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
Villain, not for thy life: Take up my Mistress
gown for thy masters use.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why sir, what is your conceit in that?

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p:
O sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for:
Take up my Mistress gown to his masters use.
O fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Hortensio, say thou wilt see the Tailor paid:
Go take it hence, be gone, and say no more.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tailor, I will pay thee for thy gown tomorrow,
Take no unkindness of his hasty words:
Away I say, commend me to thy master.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well, come my Kate, we will unto your fathers,
Even in these honest mean habiliments:
Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor:
For it is the mind that makes the body rich.
And as the Sun breaks through the darkest clouds,
So honour peereth in the meanest habit.
What is the Jay more precious than the Lark?
Because his feathers are more beautiful.
Or is the Adder better than the Eel,
Because his painted skin contents the eye.
O no good Kate: neither art thou the worse
For this poor furniture, and mean array.
If thou accountedest it shame, lay it on me,
And therefore frolic, we will hence forthwith,
To feast and sport us at thy fathers house,
Go call my men, and let us straight to him,
And bring our horses unto Long-lane end,
There will we mount, and thither walk on foot,
Let us see, I think it is now some seven o'clock,
And well we may come there by dinner time.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I dare assure you sir, it is almost two,
And it will be supper time ere you come there.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It shall be seven ere I go to horse:
Look what I speak, or do, or think to do,
You are still crossing it, sirs let it alone,
I will not go today, and ere I do,
It shall be what o'clock I say it is.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why so this gallant will command the sun.

div2.stage: Enter Tranio, and the Pedant drest like Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sirs, this is the house, please it you that I call.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Aye what else, and but I be deceived,
Seignior Baptista may remember me
Near twenty years ago in Genoa.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Where we were lodgers, at the Pegasus,
It is well, and hold your own in any case
With such austerity as longeth to a father.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I warrant you: but sir here comes your boy,
It were good he were schooled.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Fear you not him: sirrah Biondello,
Now do your duty thoroughly I advise you:
Imagine it were the right Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: Tut, fear not me.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: I told him that your father was at Venice,
And that you looked for him this day in Padua.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Thou art a tall fellow, hold thee that to drink,
Here comes Baptista: set your countenance sir.

div2.stage: Enter Baptista and Lucentio: Pedant booted and bare headed.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Seignior Baptista you are happily met:
Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of,
I pray you stand good father to me now,
Give me Bianca for my patrimony.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Soft son: sir by your leave, having come to Padua
To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio
Made me acquainted with a weighty cause
Of love between your daughter and himself:
And for the good report I hear of you,
And for the love he beareth to your daughter,
And she to him: to stay him not too long,
I am content in a good fathers care
To have him matched, and if you please to like
No worse than I, upon some agreement
Me shall you find ready and willing
With one consent to have her so bestowed:
For curious I cannot be with you
Seignior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say,
Your plainness and your shortness please me well:
Right true it is your son Lucentio here
Doth love my daughter, and she loveth him,
Or both dissemble deeply their affections:
And therefore if you say no more than this,
That like a Father you will deal with him,
And pass my daughter a sufficient dower,
The match is made, and all is done,
Your son shall have my daughter with consent.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I thank you sir, where then do you know best
We be affied and such assurance taken,
As shall with either parts agreement stand.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Not in my house Lucentio, for you know
Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants,
Besides old Gremio is harkening still,
And happily we might be interrupted.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then at my lodging, if it like you,
There doth my father lie: and there this night
We will pass the business privately and well:
Send for your daughter by your servant here,
My Boy shall fetch the Scrivener presently,
The worst is this that at so slender warning,
You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: It likes me well:
Cambio hie you home, and bid Bianca make her ready
straight:
And if you will tell what hath happened,
Lucentios Father is arrived in Padua,
And how she is like to be Lucentios wife.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.l: I pray the gods she may withal my heart.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.l: Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone.
Seignior Baptista, shall I lead the way,
Welcome, one mess is like to be your cheer,
Come sir, we will better it in Pisa.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: I follow you.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: Cambio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What sayst thou Biondello.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p:
You saw my Master wink and laugh upon
you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Biondello, what of that?

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p:
Faith nothing: but has left me here behind
to expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I pray thee moralise them.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p:
Then thus: Baptista is safe talking with the
deceiving Father of a deceitful son.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And what of him?

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p:
His daughter is to be brought by you to the
supper.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And then.

sp.speaker: Bio.
sp.p:
The old Priest at Saint Lukes Church is at your
command at all hours.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And what of all this.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p:
I cannot tell, expect they are busied about a
counterfeit assurance: take you assurance of her, Cum preuilegio ad Impremendum solem, to the Church take the
Priest, Clarke, and some sufficient honest witnesses:
sp.l: If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say,
But bid Bianca farewell for ever and a day.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hearest thou Biondello.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p:
I cannot tarry: I knew a wench married in an
afternoon as she went to the Garden for Parsley to
stuff a Rabbit, and so may you sir: and so adieu sir, my
Master hath appointed me to go to Saint Lukes to bid
the Priest be ready to come against you come with your
appendix.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I may and will, if she be so contented:
She will be pleased, then wherefore should I doubt:
Hap what hap may, I will roundly go about her:
It shall go hard if Cambio go without her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Come on a Gods name, once more toward our
fathers:
Good Lord how bright and goodly shines the Moon.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: The Moon, the Sun: it is not Moonlight
now.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I say it is the Moon that shines so bright.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I know it is the Sun that shines so bright.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now by my mothers son, and that is myself,
It shall be moon, or star, or what I list,
Or ere I journey to your Fathers house:
Go on, and fetch our horses back again,
Evermore crossed and crossed, nothing but crossed.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Say as he says, or we shall never go.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Forward I pray, since we have come so far,
And be it moon, or sun, or what you please:
And if you please to call it a rush Candle,
Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I say it is the Moon.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I know it is the Moon.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nay then you lie: it is the blessed Sun.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Then God be blessed, it in the blessed sun,
But sun it is not, when you say it is not,
And the Moon changes even as your mind:
What you will have it named, even that it is,
And so it shall be so for Katherine.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Petruchio, go thy ways, the field is won.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Well, forward, forward, thus the bowl should run,
And not unluckily against the Bias:
But soft, Company is coming here.
Good morrow gentle Mistress, where away:
Tell me sweet Kate, and tell me truly too,
Hast thou beheld a fresher Gentlewoman:
Such war of white and red within her cheeks:
What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty,
As those two eyes become that heavenly face?
Fair lovely Maid, once more good day to thee:
Sweet Kate embrace her for her beauties sake.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p:
He will make the man mad to make the woman
of him.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Young budding Virgin, fair, and fresh,and sweet,
Whether away, or whether is thy abode?
Happy the Parents of so fair a child;
Happier the man whom favourable stars
Allots thee for his lovely bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why how now Kate, I hope thou art not mad,
This is a man old, wrinkled, faded, withered,
And not a Maiden, as thou sayst he is.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Pardon old father my mistaking eyes,
That have been so bedazzled with the sun,
That everything I look on seemeth green:
Now I perceive thou art a reverent Father:
Pardon I pray thee for my mad mistaking.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Do good old grandsire, and withal make known
Which way thou travellest, if along with us,
We shall be joyful of thy company.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Fair Sir, and you my merry Mistress,
That with your strange encounter much amazed me:
My name is called Vincentio, my dwelling Pisa,
And bound I am to Padua, there to visit
A son of mine, which long I have not seen.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Lucentio gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Happily met, the happier for thy son:
And now by Law, as well as reverent age,
I may entitle thee my loving Father,
The sister to my wife, this Gentlewoman,
Thy Son by this hath married: wonder not,
Nor be not grieved, she is of good esteem,
Her dowry wealthy, and of worthy birth;
Beside, so qualified, as may beseem
The Spouse of any noble Gentleman:
Let me embrace with old Vincentio,
And wander we to see thy honest son,
Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: But is this true, or is it else your pleasure,
Like pleasant travellers to break a Jest
Upon the company you overtake?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I do assure thee father so it is.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Come go along and see the truth hereof,
For our first merriment hath made thee jealous.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Well Petruchio, this has put me in heart;
Have to my Widow, and if she froward,
Then hast thou taught Hortentio to be untoward.

div2.stage: Enter Biondello, Lucentio and Bianea, Gremio is out before.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p: Softly and swiftly sir, for the Priest is ready.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I fly Biondello; but they may chance to need
thee at home, therefore leave us.

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p:
Nay faith, I will see the Church at your back,
and then come back to my mistress as soon as I can.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.

div2.stage: Enter Petruchio, Kate, Vincentio, Grumio with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Sir here is the door, this is Lucentios house,
My Fathers bears more toward the Market-place,
Thither must I, and here I leave you sir.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You shall not choose but drink before you go,
I think I shall command your welcome here;
And by all likelihood some cheer is toward.

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.p:
They are busy within, you were best knock
louder.

div2.stage: Pedant lookes out of the window.

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.p:
What is he that knocks as he would beat down
the gate?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Is Seignior Lucentio within sir?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: He is within sir, but not to be spoken withal.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p:
What if a man bring him a hundred pound or
two to make merry withal.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Keep your hundred pounds to yourself, he
shall need none so long as I live.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in
Padua: do you hear sir, to leave frivolous circumstances, I pray you tell seignior Lucentio that his Father is
come from Pisa, and is here at the door to speak with
him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Thou liest his Father is come from Padua, and
here looking out at the window.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Art thou his father?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Aye sir, so his mother says, if I may believe her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Why how now gentleman: why this is flat knavery to take upon you another man's name.

sp.speaker: Peda.
sp.p:
Lay hands on the villain, I believe he means
to cousin somebody in this City under my countenance.

sp.speaker: Bio.
sp.p:
I have seen them in the Church together, God
send them good shipping: but who is here? mine old Master Uincentio: now we are undone and brought to nothing.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p: Come hither crack-hemp.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: I hope I may choose Sir.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Come hither you rogue, what have you forgot
me?

sp.speaker: Biond.
sp.p:
Forgot you, no sir: I could not forget you, for
I never saw you before in all my life.

sp.speaker: Uinc.
sp.p:
What, you notorious villain, didst thou never
see thy Mistress father, Vincentio?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p:
What my old worshipful old master? yes
marry sir see where he looks out of the window.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p: Is it so indeed.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p: Help, help, help, here is a mad man will murder me.

sp.speaker: Pedan.
sp.p: Help, son, help seignior Baptista.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
prithee Kate let us stand aside and see the end of
this controversy.

div2.stage: Enter Pedant with seruants, Baptista, Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p:
What am I sir: nay what are you sir: O immortal Goddess: O fine villain, a silken doublet, a velvet hose, a scarlet cloak, and a copataine hat: O I am
undone, I am undone: while I play the good husband
at home, my son and my servant spend all at the university.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: How now, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.p: What is the man lunatic?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
Sir, you seem a sober ancient Gentleman by
your habit: but your words show you a mad man: why
sir, what concerns it you, if I wear Pearl and gold: I thank
my good Father, I am able to maintain it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Thy father: O villain, he is a Sailmaker in
Bergamo.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p:
You mistake sir, you mistake sir, pray what do
you think is his name?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
His name, as if I knew not his name: I have
brought him up ever since he was three years old, and
his name is Tronio.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Away, away mad ass, his name is Lucentio, and
he is mine only son and heir to the Lands of me seignior Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p:
Lucentio: O he hath murdered his Master; lay
hold on him I charge you in the Dukes name: O my
son, my son: tell me thou villain, where is my son
Lucentio?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
Call forth an officer: Carry this mad knave to
the Jail: father Baptista, I charge you see that he be
forth coming.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Carry me to the Jail?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Stay officer, he shall not go to prison.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p:
Talk not seignior Gremio: I say he shall go to
prison.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p:
Take heed seignior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business: I dare swear this is the right
Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Swear if thou darest.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Nay, I dare not swear it.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Yes, I know thee to be seignior Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Away with the dotard, to the Jail with him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Thus strangers may be hailed and abused: O monstrous villain.

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.p:
O we are spoiled, and yonder he is, deny him,
forswear him, or else we are all undone.

div2.stage: Exit Biondello, Tranio and Pedant as fast as may be.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pardon sweet father.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Lives my sweet son?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Pardon dear father.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: How hast thou offended, where is Lucentio?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Here is Lucentio, right son to the right Uincentio,
That have by marriage made thy daughter mine,
While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyen.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Here is packing with a witness to deceive us all.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Where is that damned villain Tranio,
That faced and braved me in this matter so?

sp.speaker: Bup.
sp.l: Why, tell me is not this my Cambio?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Love wrought these miracles. Biancas love
Made me exchange my state with Tranio,
While he did bear my countenance in the town,
And happily I have arrived at the last
Unto the wished haven of my bliss:
What Tranio did, myself enforced him to;
Then pardon him sweet Father for my sake.

sp.speaker: Uin.
sp.p:
I will slit the villains nose that would have sent
me to the Jail.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p:
But do you hear sir, have you married my
daughter without asking my good will?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Fear not Baptista, we will content you, go to:
but I will in to be revenged for this villainy.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: And I to sound the depth of this knavery.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Look not pale Bianca, thy father will not frown.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: My cake is dough, but I will in among the rest,
Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Husband let us follow, to see the end of this ado.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: First kiss me Kate, and we will.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: What in the midst of the street?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: What art thou ashamed of me?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: No sir, God forbid, but ashamed to kiss.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why then let us home again: Come Sirrah let us
away.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Nay, I will give thee a kiss, now pray thee
Love stay.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Is not this well? come my sweet Kate.
Better once than never, for never too late.

div2.stage: Enter Baptista, Vincentio, Gremio, the Pedant, Lucentio, and Bianca. Tranio, Biondello Grumio, and Widdow: The Seruingmen with Tranio bringing in a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: At last, though long, our jarring notes agree,
And time it is when raging war is come,
To smile at scapes and perils overblown:
My fair Bianca bid my father welcome,
While I with selfsame kindness welcome thine:
Brother Petruchio, sister Katerina,
And thou Hortentio with thy loving Widow:
Feast with the best, and welcome to my house,
My Banquet is to close our stomachs up
After our great good cheer: pray you sit down,
For now we sit to chat as well as eat.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: For both our sakes I would that word were true.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now for my life Hortentio fears his Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Then never trust me if I be afeared.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my
sense:
I mean Hortentio is afeared of you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Roundly replied.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Mistress, how mean you that?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Thus I conceive by him.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Conceives by me, how likes Hortentio that?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Widow says, thus she conceives her tale.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Very well mended: kiss him for that good
Widow.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round,
I pray you tell me what you meant by that.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Your husband being troubled with a shrew,
Measures my husbands sorrow by his woe:
And now you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: A very mean meaning.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Right, I mean you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: To her Kate.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: To her Widow.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: That is my office

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Spoke like an Officer: ha to the lad.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: How likes Gremio these quick witted folks?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Believe me sir, they But together well.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Head, and but an hasty witted body,
Would say your Head and But were head and horn.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Aye Mistress Bride, hath that awakened you?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Aye, but not frighted me, therefore I will sleep again.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nay that you shall not since you have begun:
Have at you for a better jest or two.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Am I your Bird, I mean to shift my bush,
And then pursue me as you draw your Bow.
You are welcome all.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: She hath prevented me, here seignior Tranio,
This bird you aimed at, though you hit her not,
Therefore a health to all that shot and missed.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: O sir, Lucentio slipped me like his Gray-hound,
Which runs himself, and catches for his Master.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A good swift simile, but something currish.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: It is well sir that you hunted for yourself:
It is thought your Deer does hold you at a bay.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: O, O Petruchio, Tranio hits you now.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I thank thee for that gird good Tranio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He has a little galled me I confess:
And as the Jest did glance away from me,
It is ten to one it maimed you too out right.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Now in good sadness son Petruchio,
I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Well, I say no: and therefore sir assurance,
let us each one send unto his wife,
And he whose wife is most obedient,
To come at first when he doth send for her,
Shall win the wager which we will propose.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Content, what is the wager?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Twenty crowns.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Twenty crowns,
I will venture so much of my Hawk or Hound,
But twenty times so much upon my Wife.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A hundred then.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A match, it is done.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Who shall begin?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That will I.
Go Biondello, bid your Mistress come to me.

sp.speaker: Bio.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Son, I will be your half, Bianca comes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will have no halves: I will bear it all myself.
How now, what news?

sp.speaker: Bio.
sp.l: Sir, my Mistress sends you word
That she is busy, and she cannot come.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: How? she is busy, and she cannot come: is that
an answer?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Aye, and a kind one too:
Pray God sir your wife send you not a worse.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I hope better.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife to
come to me forthwith.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O ho, entreat her, nay then she must needs
come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I am afraid sir, do what you can
Yours will not be entreated: Now, where is my wife?

sp.speaker: Bion.
sp.l: She says you have some goodly Jest in hand,
She will not come: she bids you come to her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Worse and worse, she will not come:
O vild, intolerable, not to be endured:
Sirrah Grumio, go to your Mistress,
Say I command her come to me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I know her answer.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She will not.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Now by my hollidame here comes Katerina.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: What is your will sir, that you send for me?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Where is your sister, and Hortensios wife?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: They sit conferring by the Parlour fire.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Go fetch them hither, if they deny to come,
Swing me them soundly forth unto their husbands:
Away I say, and bring them hither straight.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And so it is: I wonder what it bodes.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Marry peace it bodes, and love, and quiet life,
An awful rule, and right supremacy:
And to be short, what not, that is sweet and happy.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Now fair befall thee good Petruchio;
The wager thou hast won, and I will add
Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns,
Another dowry to another daughter,
For she is changed as she had never been.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nay, I will win my wager better yet,
And show more sign of her obedience,
Her new built virtue and obedience.
See where she comes, and brings your froward Wives
As prisoners to her womanly persuasion:
Katerine, that Cap of yours becomes you not,
Off with that bauble, throw it underfoot.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Lord let me never have a cause to sigh,
Till I be brought to such a silly pass.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Fie what a foolish duty call you this?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I would your duty were as foolish too:
The wisdom of your duty fair Bianca,
Hath cost me five hundred crowns since supper time.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: The more fool you for laying on my duty.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Katherine I charge thee tell these head-strong
women, what duty they do owe their Lords and husbands.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Come, come, your mocking: we will have no
telling.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Come on I say, and first begin with her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: She shall not.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I say she shall, and first begin with her.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Fie, fie, unknit that threatening unkind brow,
And dart not scornful glances from those eyes,
To wound thy Lord, thy King, thy Governor.
It blots thy beauty, as frosts do bite the Meads,
Confounds thy fame, as whirlwinds shake fair buds,
And in no sense is meet or amiable.
A woman moved, is like a fountain troubled,
Muddy, ill seeming, thick, bereft of beauty,
And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty
Will deign to sip, or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy Lord, thy life, thy keeper,
Thy head, thy sovereign: One that cares for thee,
And for thy maintenance. Commits his body
To painful labour, both by sea and land:
To watch the night in storms, the day in cold,
Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe,
And craves no other tribute at thy hands,
But love, fair looks, and true obedience;
Too little payment for so great a debt.
Such duty as the subject owes the Prince,
Even such a woman oweth to her husband:
And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour,
And not obedient to his honest will,
What is she but a foul contending Rebel,
And graceless Traitor to her loving Lord?
I am ashamed that women are so simple,
To offer war, where they should kneel for peace:
Or seek for rule, supremacy, and sway,
When they are bound to serve, love, and obey.
Why are our bodies soft, and weak, and smooth,
Unapt to toil and trouble in the world,
But that our soft conditions, and our hearts,
Should well agree with our external parts?
Come, come, you froward and unable worms,
My mind hath been as big as one of yours,
My heart as great, my reason happily more,
To bandy word for word, and frown for frown;
But now I see our Lances are but straws:
Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare,
That seeming to be most, which we indeed least are.
Then vale your stomachs, for it is no boot,
And place your hands below your husbands foot:
In token of which duty, if he please,
My hand is ready, may it do him ease.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why there is a wench: Come on, and kiss me
Kate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Well go thy ways old Lad for thou shalt have it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: It is a good hearing, when children are toward.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But a harsh hearing, when women are froward,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Come Kate, we will to bed,
We three are married, but you two are sped.
It was I won the wager, though you hit the white,
And being a winner, God give you good night.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: Now go thy ways, thou hast tamed a cursed
Shrew.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.
